channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Jerusalem Journal: A-List Celebration Traces Leader’s Trajectory, and Israel’s
item.description: Dignitaries and celebrities gathered to fete President Shimon Peres of Israel, already the world’s oldest leader, who turns 90 in August.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Shimon Peres turns 90 in August. He is the last of Israel’s founding fathers still in office, and in recent months has strained his largely ceremonial role by speaking out on resolving the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

item.title: Obama Has Plans to Cut U.S. Nuclear Arsenal, if Russia Reciprocates
item.description: In a speech in Berlin on Wednesday, the President Obama will resume a drive toward disarmament that had been largely shunted aside.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: President Obama and his wife, Michelle, were greeted by an honor guard in Berlin on Tuesday.

item.title: Extending a Hand Abroad, Obama Often Finds a Cold Shoulder
item.description: For all of his effort to cultivate personal ties with foreign counterparts over the last four and a half years, Mr. Obama has complicated relationships with some, and has bet on others who came to disappoint him.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and PETER BAKER
item.media:description: President Obama had a chilly meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Monday.

item.title: A More Secular Europe, Divided by the Cross
item.description: A commemorative euro coin with Christian imagery became the latest source of discord between the profoundly religious and those who prize a more rigid church-state divide.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: A huge European Union flag in front of the Parliament building in Bucharest, Romania, in May. The flag, with its circle of 12 yellow stars, has a coded Christian message, inspired by iconography of the Virgin Mary wearing a crown with 12 stars.

item.title: Protests Widen as Brazilians Chide Leaders
item.description: Demonstrators remained defiant Tuesday, pouring into the streets by the thousands and venting their anger over political corruption, the high cost of living and huge public spending for the World Cup and the Olympics.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO
item.media:description: President Dilma Rousseff said that Brazil "awoke stronger" after the protests on Monday night.

item.title: Taliban Step Toward Afghan Peace Talks Is Hailed by U.S.
item.description: The Taliban announced the opening of a political office in Doha, Qatar, on Tuesday and said they were prepared to talk, raising hopes for a break in long-stalled peace efforts.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG and ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: Taliban officials cut the ribbon at the official opening ceremony of a political office in Doha, Qatar on Tuesday.

item.title: The Lede: Protests Expand in Brazil, Fueled by Video of Police Brutality
item.description: Protests in Brazil against the high cost of living and lavish spending on soccer stadiums ahead of next year’s World Cup have intensified as images of police brutality against peaceful protesters spread on social networks.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: N.S.A. Chief Says Surveillance Has Stopped Dozens of Plots
item.description: Gen. Keith B. Alexander said on Tuesday that American surveillance had helped prevent “potential terrorist events over 50 times since 9/11.”
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE
item.media:description: Gen. Keith B. Alexander, director of the National Security Agency, testified before the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence on Tuesday.

item.title: Islamists Press Blasphemy Cases in a New Egypt
item.description: The number of blasphemy cases, once rare in Egypt, has increased sharply as Islamists assert their new power in public life.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD and MAYY EL SHEIKH
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Deir El Gabrawi, a poor Christian village. A school secretary in the village was sentenced to prison on blasphemy charges.

item.title: Turkey Arrests Dozens in Crackdown on Protests
item.description: The Turkish police arrested dozens of people in several cities early Tuesday as part of an intensifying crackdown against recent protests.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIMI and SEBNEM ARSU
item.media:description: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan claimed victory over Turkey's anti-government protesters after the arrests of dozens, but demonstrators began silent protests on Taksim Square in Istanbul, on Tuesday.

item.title: Special Report: Energy: Harnessing the Net to Power a Green Revolution
item.description: A new generation of entrepreneurs is finding innovative ways of using information technology to make everyday life more efficient.
item.dc:creator: By BETH GARDINER
item.media:description: A solar project in Oakland, Calif. by Mosaic, a crowdfunding platform that links individual investors to solar energy projects that reduce the use of fossil fuels.

item.title: Reception for Obama Is More Sober Than in 2008
item.description: The president’s arrival in Berlin is being greeted with far less fanfare than when he gave a speech as a candidate in 2008.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: Irish Lawmakers Expected to Approve Limited Abortion
item.description: The legislation would allow terminations in cases when there is a real and substantial risk to the life of the mother, including the threat of suicide, and details the circumstances.
item.category: Protection of Life During Pregnancy Bill 2013
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS DALBY

item.title: Special Report: Energy: Utilities Switch Off Investment in Fossil Fuel Plants
item.description: Europe could be headed for a damaging power shortage as competition from green energy and weak demand mean few companies want to invest in infrastructure.
item.dc:creator: By MARK SCOTT
item.media:description: A coal plant run by E.On of Germany. E.On and other European utilities have announced plans to shut down less-polluting natural gas-fired plants that have been undercut by dirtier coal-burning generators.

item.title: Blast Apparently Aimed at an Afghan Politician Kills 3 in Kabul
item.description: An explosion heard across Kabul on Tuesday morning appeared aimed at killing a prominent ethnic Hazara politician as he was traveling in his armored convoy.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN and SHARIFULLAH SAHAK

item.title: Special Report: Energy: Gas Prices Moving Away From Link to Oil
item.description: Unlike oil, which is a globally traded commodity, gas is priced depending on location and the particular arrangement under which it is sold.
item.dc:creator: By STANLEY REED

item.title: Baikonur Journal: Russian Space Center in Kazakhstan Counts Down Its Days of Glory
item.description: Baikonur will be replaced as the Russian space launching center, and already faces ethnic tensions and economic challenges.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police officers with a Soyuz rocket before it was taken to its launchpad to send astronauts to the International Space Station.

item.title: Obama and Putin Signal a More Businesslike Path
item.description: At a joint appearance on the sidelines of the Group of 8 meeting, there was tension but also common ground, to the chagrin of human rights advocates.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Barack Obama and Vladimir V. Putin during the Group of 8 conference in Northern Ireland.

item.title: World Brief | Africa : Six Men Sentenced for Attacking Sufi Shrine in Tunisia
item.description: A Tunisian court sentenced the men, ultraconservative Salafi Muslims, to five years in prison for attacking visitors to a Sufi shrine in Tunis.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Rebels in North Mali Sign Peace Deal Allowing In Government Troops
item.description: Rebels whose revolt last year split Mali signed a peace deal with the government, resolving a stumbling block to the West African nation’s reconstruction.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Syrian Tensions Spill Into a City in Southern Lebanon
item.description: At least two people were reported killed in sectarian clashes in the Mediterranean port of Sidon, underscoring the Syrian conflict’s effects in Lebanon.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HANIA MOURTADA and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: G-8 Meeting Ends With Cordial Stalemate on Syria
item.description: The United States and leaders of other major industrialized nations averted a clash with President Vladimir Putin of Russia by avoiding mention of the most contentious matters that divided them.
item.dc:creator: By JACKIE CALMES and STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: India Ink: Fatal Floods Hit North India
item.description: Flash floods in northern India, which have killed at least 70 people over the past four days, have stranded 30,000 tourists and pilgrims in the Himalayan states of Uttarakhand and Himachal Pradesh.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: Army soldiers rescuing stranded villagers in the aftermath of floods triggered by heavy rain in Yamunanagar district of Haryana on Monday.

item.title: Hungarian Charged With War Crimes for Actions in World War II
item.description: Laszlo Csatary, now 98, is accused of helping to send nearly 12,000 Hungarian Jews to Nazi death camps.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Suicide Bombers Kill 37 at Shiite Mosque in Baghdad
item.description: The mosque bombing made Tuesday the third consecutive day of sectarian attacks in Iraq this week.
item.dc:creator: By YASIR GHAZI
